channel.title: Bloomberg Politics

item.title: Israel Accepts Gaza Deal Restoring UN Aid as Hamas Remains Wary
item.description: Israel has accepted a US ceasefire proposal for Gaza that Israeli officials familiar with the matter said would involve a 60-day pause in the fighting and restore UN-led aid distribution to the enclave.
item.dc:creator: Dan Williams, Fares Alghoul

media:content.media:description: Palestinians carry boxes of humanitarian aid collected from a distribution center in the Netzarim Corridor, central Gaza Strip, on Thursday, May 29, 2025. The US and Israel-backed Gaza Humanitarian Foundation says it opened a fourth distribution site and three of its four sites were fully operational and dispensed aid on Thursday.

item.title: Trump Aims to Boost Taiwan Arms Sales Further, Reuters Says
item.description: President Donald Trump is planning to ramp up weapons sales to Taiwan to a level exceeding the pace set during his first term, Reuters reported, a move that risks escalating military tensions with China at a time the two nations are already locked in difficult talks over tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Jenni Marsh

media:content.media:description: A Taiwanese flag flies during the National Day celebration in Taipei, Taiwan, on Thursday, Oct. 10, 2024. Taiwan President Lai Ching-te indicated in a speech that he would stand up to the challenges posed by China, comments likely to elicit a sharp response from Beijing. Photographer: An Rong Xu/Bloomberg

item.title: Poland’s Tight Election Puts Europe on Alert for Another Jolt
item.description: The runoff vote for president has become a referendum on Poland’s role in Europe, women’s rights and support for neighboring Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Ojewska, Maciej Martewicz

media:content.media:description: Campaign banners for presidential candidates Karol Nawrocki and Rafal Trzaskowski in the Polish city of Opole.

item.title: North Korea’s Surging Military Aid to Russia Detailed in Report
item.description: North Korea has become a crucial source of missiles, munitions and even soldiers for Russia’s war in Ukraine as the sanctions-defying alliance between the two countries intensifies, according to a report by 11 countries, including the US and Japan.
item.dc:creator: John Harney

media:content.media:description: TOPSHOT - Korean People's Army (KPA) soldiers march during a mass rally on Kim Il Sung square in Pyongyang on September 9, 2018. North Korea was marking the 70th anniversary of its founding.Korean People's Army (KPA) tanks take part in a military parade on Kim Il Sung square in Pyongyang on September 9, 2018. (Photo by Ed JONES / AFP) / "The erroneous mention[s] appearing in the metadata of this photo has been modified in AFP systems in the following manner: [BYLINE - ED JONES]. Please immediately remove the erroneous mention[s] from all your online services and delete it (them) from your servers. If you have been authorized by AFP to distribute it (them) to third parties, please ensure that the same actions are carried out by them. Failure to promptly comply with these instructions will entail liability on your part for any continued or post notification usage. Therefore we thank you very much for all your attention and prompt action. We are sorry for the inconvenience this notification may cause and remain at your disposal for any further information you may require." (Photo by ED JONES/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Chinese Students Ditch US Plans as Trump Vows Crackdown on Visas
item.description: The Trump administration’s move to revoke visas for Chinese students is upending Anqi Dong’s dream of a US education even before it starts.
item.dc:creator: Filipe Pacheco, Amanda Wang, Francesca Maglione

media:content.media:description: In this picture taken on December 10, 2021, a woman visits the US embassy in Beijing. (Photo by Jade GAO / AFP) (Photo by JADE GAO/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Trump-Ishiba Call Gives Akazawa Momentum for Trade Talks
item.description: Japan’s top trade negotiator Ryosei Akazawa is heading into the latest round of trade negotiations with the US with some added momentum, following a phone call between Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba and President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Shigeru Ishiba and Donald Trump. Photographer: Kyodo News/Kyodo News Stills

item.title: Trump Will Hold Press Conference With Musk as He Departs DOGE
item.description: President Donald Trump will hold a news conference at the White House alongside Elon Musk on Friday to mark the departure of the world’s richest man from his official role leading an effort to slash the size and scope of the US government.
item.dc:creator: Derek Wallbank, Gregory Korte

media:content.media:description: WASHINGTON, DC - MARCH 9: White House Senior Advisor Elon Musk walks to the White House after landing in Marine One on the South Lawn with U.S. President Donald Trump (not pictured) on March 9, 2025 in Washington, DC. Trump was returning to the White House after spending the weekend at Mar-a-Lago, his private club in Florida. (Photo by Samuel Corum/Getty Images)

item.title: Trump Wins Tariff Reprieve as Trade Agenda Faces Rollback
item.description: A federal appeals court offered President Donald Trump a temporary reprieve from a ruling threatening to throw out the bulk of his sweeping tariff agenda, giving at least some hope to a White House now facing substantial new restrictions on its effort to rewrite the global trading order.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Jennifer A Dlouhy

item.title: Bessent Says US-China Talks ‘Stalled,’ Pushes for Trump-Xi Call
item.description: US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said trade talks with China are “a bit stalled,” and that a call between President Donald Trump and his counterpart Xi Jinping may be needed for the world’s two largest economies to reach a deal.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent during a roundtable meeting at the US Treasury Department in Washington, DC, on May 29

item.title: Taiwan Says US Trade-Deal Push Still On Despite Court Ruling
item.description: Taiwan is continuing efforts to secure a trade deal with the US, a top official in Taipei said, even after a court blocked many of the tariffs that President Donald Trump has threatened to impose on other countries.
item.dc:creator: Yian Lee, Miaojung Lin, Yvonne Man

media:content.media:description: The Port of Keelung in Keelung, Taiwan.

item.title: Trump-Xi Truce Under Threat After US Targets Chinese Students, Tech
item.description: Just weeks after US President Donald Trump declared a “total reset” with China following a trade truce in Geneva, tensions are rising again between the world’s biggest economies.
item.dc:creator: Colum Murphy

media:content.media:description: The Harry Elkins Widener Memorial Library at Harvard University in Cambridge, Massachusetts, on May 27. Photographer: Sophie Park/Bloomberg

item.title: UK Business Confidence Hits 9-Month High in Boost for Starmer
item.description: A gauge of UK business confidence rose to a nine-month high, climbing back to a level not seen since soon after Prime Minister Keir Starmer first took power, as markets rebounded and trade tensions eased with the US.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel

item.title: Synopsys Suspends Guidance After US Notice on Export Curbs
item.description: Synopsys Inc., a top maker of chip-design software, suspended its financial guidance for the current quarter and fiscal year after receiving word from the US government about new restrictions on exports to China.
item.dc:creator: Ian King

media:content.media:description: Synopsys headquarters in Mountain View, California.

item.title: State Department Plans to Close Office That Aids Afghan Refugees
item.description: The US State Department has notified Congress that it will shut down the office that helped resettle Afghan refugees who assisted the American war effort, provoking an outcry from nonprofit groups that helped evacuate people when the Taliban retook control of the country in 2021.
item.dc:creator: Hadriana Lowenkron

media:content.media:description: Signage is displayed outside the U.S. State Department headquarters in Washington, D.C., U.S., on Thursday, Oct. 3, 2019. Aides to Secretary of State Michael Pompeo cautioned against unfounded reports suggesting that the U.S. Embassy in Ukraine was a hotbed of Democratic support, according to documents turned over to Congress Wednesday by the State Department's watchdog.

item.title: BOE’s Bailey Urges Closer EU Trade to Reverse Brexit Damage
item.description: Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey has urged the government to strike a deeper trade deal with the European Union to improve growth and “minimize negative effects” of Brexit.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick, Tom Rees, Irina Anghel, Francine Lacqua

media:content.media:description: Andrew Bailey, governor of the Bank of England (BOE), at the Monetary Policy Report news conference at the bank's headquarters in the City of London, UK, on Thursday, May 8, 2025. The Bank of England cut interest rates by a quarter point to 4.25% as Donald Trump’s global trade war weighs on UK growth, in a decision that split senior officials into three groups and was made before the US President hinted at an imminent deal to lower tariffs on British exports.

item.title: Pulte Sees No Scenario Where Trump Isn’t in Control of Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac
item.description: Federal Housing Finance Agency Director Bill Pulte said he cannot envision a situation where President Donald Trump relinquishes control of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, emphasizing there is a need to keep implicit guarantees intact as the administration considers potential options for the two mortgage giants.
item.dc:creator: Norah Mulinda

media:content.media:description: William Pulte, director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency (FHFA) nominee for US President Donald Trump, during a Senate Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs Committee confirmation hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, Feb. 27, 2025. Stephen Miran, President Donald Trump's pick to head the White House Council of Economic Advisers, called for an industrial policy centered on building up US defense capabilities.

item.title: Reform’s Farage Gives Trump-Style Bid to Make UK Crypto Hub
item.description: Reform UK leader Nigel Farage attempted to woo younger British voters by announcing a Donald Trump-style foray into cryptocurrency policy at a Bitcoin conference in Las Vegas late on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White

media:content.media:description: Nigel Farage on May 27.

item.title: Obscure Tax Item in Trump’s Big Bill Alarms Wall Street
item.description: Buried deep in the more than 1,000-page tax-and-spending bill that President Donald Trump is muscling through Congress is an obscure tax measure that’s setting off alarms on Wall Street and beyond.
item.dc:creator: Ye Xie, Liz Capo McCormick

item.title: Hochul and Murphy Break Ground on $10 Billion NYC Bus Terminal
item.description: New York Governor Kathy Hochul and New Jersey Governor Phil Murphy broke ground Thursday on a $10 billion redevelopment of Manhattan’s bus terminal, the busiest in the world.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Kaske

media:content.media:description: New Jersey Governor Phil Murphy and New York Governor Kathy Hochul attend the ground breaking for a new Midtown Bus Terminal on May 29, 2025 in New York City. The 10-year, $10 billion project replaces the decades-old Port Authority Bus Terminal.

item.title: Libya Detains Three in State Oil Attack to Defuse Supply Threat
item.description: Libya’s attorney general ordered the detention of three people accused of storming the state oil company’s headquarters after authorities in the country’s eastern half threatened to shut oil output in response to the episode.
item.dc:creator: Hatem Mohareb

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of Libya's National Oil Corporation in Tripoli, Libya, on July 14, 2022.

item.title: Appeals Court Allows Trump Tariffs to Stay in Effect for Now
item.description: A federal appeals court temporarily paused a sweeping ruling against President Donald Trump’s global tariffs while it takes more time to consider the administration’s request for a longer-lasting hold.
item.dc:creator: Erik Larson

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump Photographer: Chris Kleponis/CNP/Bloomberg

item.title: Where Does Trump’s Trade War Go With Tariffs in Legal Limbo?
item.description: The US Court of International Trade ruled May 28 that the vast majority of President Donald Trump’s tariffs were issued illegally and ordered them blocked, which would deliver a blow to a key pillar of his economic agenda. A day later, an appeals court gave Trump’s administration a temporarily reprieve from the ruling while weighing a longer-lasting hold.
item.dc:creator: Erik Larson, Josh Wingrove, Shawn Donnan, Laura Curtis

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump holds a poster detailing the reciprocal tariffs during an announcement in the White House Rose Garden in Washington, DC, on April 2, 2025. Photographer: Kent Nishimura/Bloomberg

item.title: Ford Says Michigan Battery Plant at Risk If Tax Credits Are Cut
item.description: Ford Motor Co.’s plan to make electric-vehicle batteries at a new site in Michigan would be put at risk if Congress cuts federal incentives for clean energy, the company’s chair said.
item.dc:creator: Keith Naughton, Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: Bill Ford announces at a press conference that Ford will be partnering with the world's largest battery company, the Chinese firm Contemporary Amperex Technology, to create an electric-vehicle battery plant in Marshall, Michigan, on Feb. 13, 2023.

item.title: Federal Job Seekers Will Be Quizzed on Trump’s Executive Orders
item.description: The Trump administration is adding four essay questions to applications for civil service jobs, asking applicants about their favorite executive orders and their commitment to government efficiency.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Korte

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump signs an executive order in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC.

item.title: Trump Gets a Tariff Reprieve as Advisers Plot Out a Plan B
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Today, Treasury reporter Daniel Flatley looks at the legal battle over the legality of the president’s tariffs. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley

item.title: Harvard Reprieve From Foreign Student Ban Extended by Judge
item.description: Harvard University won a longer-term reprieve from a Trump administration ban on enrolling international students, handing the nation’s oldest and richest university a victory in its battle with the White House.
item.dc:creator: David Voreacos, Greg Ryan

media:content.media:description: Harvard University students walk through Harvard Square in Cambridge, Massachusetts, on May 29. Photographer: Mel Musto/Bloomberg

item.title: Hyundai Weighs Sweeping US Price Hikes to Blunt Tariffs
item.description: Hyundai Motor Co. is preparing to increase the price of all of its US vehicles as the automaker looks to cushion the blow from tariffs imposed by President Donald Trump, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Gabrielle Coppola

media:content.media:description: A Hyundai dealership in Houston, Texas.

item.title: Russia Accuses Serbia of Backstabbing by Helping Arm Ukraine
item.description: Russia’s spy agency accused Serbia of selling weapons to Ukraine through third countries, potentially straining a relationship with a traditional ally that relies on Moscow for energy supplies.
item.dc:creator: Misha Savic

media:content.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier loads ammunition into an M2 Browning machine gun during a handover of mobile anti-aircraft pick-up trucks by Herocar, as part of the Guardians of the Sky project, at Gostomel airfield, outside Kyiv, Ukraine, on Saturday, April 1, 2023. The International Monetary Fund’s board signed off on a $15.6 billion aid package for Ukraine, the final approval for the institution’s first-ever loan to a nation at war. Photographer: Andrew Kravchenko/Bloomberg

item.title: Atlanta’s $157 Million Highway Revamp at Risk From Trump Cuts
item.description: A $157 million plan to turn an Atlanta highway overpass into a park and provide 3,000 housing units is in jeopardy from President Donald Trump and the Republican-controlled Congress, Mayor Andre Dickens said.
item.dc:creator: Brett Pulley

media:content.media:description: Bank of America Plaza building, center, in downtown Atlanta, Georgia, U.S., on Friday, Oct. 2, 2020. Bloomberg News analyzed foot traffic data for downtown merchants in Lower Manhattan, Chicago, Atlanta, Dallas and San Francisco and compared them to merchants in five nearby suburbs for the period spanning mid-October through November -- a period that included Black Friday. The downtown merchants saw an average foot traffic decline of between 64% and 77% for the period.

item.title: Portugal’s Montenegro Is Formally Named Premier for Second Term
item.description: Portugal’s center-right leader Luis Montenegro was formally named prime minister for a second term after his ruling coalition won a snap election earlier this month.
item.dc:creator: Joao Lima

media:content.media:description: Luis Montenegro, Portugal’s prime minister, during an election night rally in Lisbon on May 18.
